Award.AwardTitle: Stress-Related Neural Responses Linking Toddler-Mother Attachment and Adolescent Adjustment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Early family relationships lay the foundation for children's successful development across the lifespan. One particularly important aspect of early family relationships is child-mother attachment security. A child whose attachment-related bids (e.g., clinging, crying) are consistently met with a timely and sensitive response by the caregiver will likely develop a secure attachment to that caregiver, whereas a child whose bids are met with rejection, hostility, or inconsistent responsiveness will likely form an insecure attachment. Variations in early attachment security play a role in 'sculpting' the brain of the developing child. Yet, we know little about the potential neurobiological mechanisms linking child-mother attachment to children's later adjustment. The goals of this research are twofold: (1) to examine how early child-mother attachment security (measured at age 2.5 years) relates to stress-related neural responses at age 13, and (2) test whether stress-related neural responses are associated with adolescent adjustment at age 14.

To carry out this work, participants will be recruited from an existing longitudinal study, the Children's Social Development Project (CSDP), in which child-mother attachment was assessed at 2.5 years. Ten years later, at age 13, mother-adolescent interactions will be observed and adolescents will be interviewed about current attachment relationships. Adolescents' neural responses in two stress-eliciting tasks will be assessed using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). At ages 13 and 14, adolescent adjustment in multiple domains will be assessed via self, maternal, and paternal reports. The proposed study will be the first of its kind to assess how child-mother attachment security in early childhood relates to stress-related neural processes and, in turn, adjustment in adolescence. Project findings have the potential to shed light on fundamental questions regarding how early experiences set the stage for later adjustment and will provide a much needed window into the extent to which typical variation in early human attachment predicts brain functioning in later development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Early child-mother attachment security yields psychological, emotional, and social benefits that support healthy development. Yet, we know little about the potential neurobiological mechanisms linking child-mother attachment to children's later adjustment. This gap is striking given the longstanding theoretical underpinnings of the attachment behavioral system as serving an evolutionary survival function rooted in the central nervous system. Although animal models provide causal evidence linking disruptions in attachment-related processes to altered neural development, studies with human children have largely examined severe adverse caregiving or have focused on one developmental period. To address this gap, we investigated the extent to which normative variation in early child-mother attachment security predicted neural responses to social and emotional stimuli at age 13. We leveraged data from an existing longitudinal study, the Children's Social Development Project (CSDP) conducted at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, in which child-mother attachment was assessed at 2.5 years using a modified Strange Situation procedure. At 13 years, adolescents' neural responses during emotionally salient tasks were assessed via functional magnetic resonance imaging, and adolescents were also interviewed about current attachment relationships. Tests of hypothesized associations controlled for concurrent attachment relationships and/or demographic variables as appropriate.

Results supported key hypotheses. Activation patterns of the fusiform gyrus and amygdala in response to faces varying in trustworthiness indicated that adolescents with a secure attachment at 2.5 years may be more capable of, and open to, processing negative social information (e.g., cues of untrustworthiness), whereas those with an insecure attachment history might engage in defensive exclusion of threatening social cues. In the context of a risk-taking task, adolescents with an insecure attachment at 2.5 years showed blunted sensitivity to increasing risk levels in the dorsal striatum, while also showing heightened sensitivity to increasing reward levels in the same region. In the context of an emotion labeling task, more positive maternal emotion socialization behaviors (which have close conceptual connections to attachment security) at 2.5 years predicted less positive (or more negative) amygdala-vmPFC connectivity, reflecting a more mature pattern of emotion regulations. Likewise, maternal sensitivity at 2.5 years predicted more negative amygdala-mPFC connectivity to both happy and angry faces at 13 years, whereas less sensitive caregiving at 2.5 years predicted more positive amygdala-mPFC connectivity pattern, suggesting a less mature pattern of emotion regulation.

This study is one of the first prospective longitudinal investigations showing that early attachment, assessed via gold-standard observational assessments (e.g., Strange Situation), predicts adolescents' neural functioning in the context of emotionally salient tasks. Our findings provide empirical support for key theoretical propositions regarding attachment as a biobehavioral system of protection that is rooted in the central nervous system. Our findings also reveal that the effects of early attachment contribute to neural function above and beyond concurrent attachment and/or demographic characteristics. This pattern of results suggests that intervention and prevention efforts during the first years of life aimed at promoting secure attachment relationships may foster healthy brain development during subsequent years.

Broader impacts of this project include training of graduate and undergraduate students in human development and affective developmental neuroscience. Students actively participated in all phases of the research, including presentation of results at national conferences and preparation of manuscripts for submission to scientific journals. We have also shared project findings with the larger community through participation in community events serving parents, children, and adolescents, including Brain Awareness Day at a local children's museum, Beckman Institute's Biennial Open House at the University of Illinois, and the Science Expo at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
